channel.title: What Time Is It?

item.title: What Time Is It?
item.dc:creator: @ownage_plz ownage plz
item.description:
@ownage_plz wrote:

public String getTime() { Calendar cal = new GregorianCalendar(); int ampm = cal.get(Calendar.AM_PM); int hour12 = cal.get(Calendar.HOUR); int min = cal.get(Calendar.MINUTE); int sec = cal.get(Calendar.SECOND); { return "Hour: "+hour12+" Min: "+min+" Sec: "+sec; } return "NaN"; }

and put getTime(); in process ?

Read full topic

item.title: What Time Is It?
item.dc:creator: @TeleNubby TeleNubby
item.description:
@TeleNubby wrote:

[quote=“ownage plz, post:6, topic:130405”]So … you want the time to write to a file ? when someone does what

"Hour: "+hour12+" Min: "+min+" Sec: "+sec

should do it.[/quote]
That gives me the time of when I logged in for some reason, not the time I wrote to the file. (Because it’s a public int and in client.java, maybe the time stays the same because the ints are declared when I start to play right? If so I’ve tried making a void that sets the times again to try and refresh, but it didnt work.)

Read full topic

item.description:
@TeleNubby wrote:

[quote=“ownage plz, post:4, topic:130405”]Do you want it as a sendquest or …

Basically put it in a void and make a call to it in the process.[/quote]
I needed the current time to write to a file and have an accurate log report.

item.title: What Time Is It?
item.dc:creator: @bakatool bakatool
item.description:
@bakatool wrote:

I would think this

Date now = new Date();

System.out.println(now.getHours() + " : " + now.getMinutes() + " : " + now.getSeconds());

but it says its Deprecated and wants people to use

Calendar.get(Calendar.HOUR_OF_DAY);
Calendar.get(Calendar.MINUTE);
Calendar.get(Calendar.SECOND);

Read full topic

Something like this?

import java.util.Calendar; import java.util.GregorianCalendar;

I’m not fully understanding what you want here.

item.title: What Time Is It?
item.dc:creator: @TeleNubby TeleNubby
item.description:
@TeleNubby wrote:

Love my Title <3

Question is, how do I get the time? Ive done this:

public Calendar cal = new GregorianCalendar();
public int ampm = cal.get(Calendar.AM_PM);   
public int hour12 = cal.get(Calendar.HOUR);
public int min = cal.get(Calendar.MINUTE); 
public int sec = cal.get(Calendar.SECOND);

But apparently… That only gives me the time I logged in. How do I get an updated time, like the current time right now?

Read full topic
